10.7692 0 0 10.7692 50 229.2321 Tm
(Tiny fragment attacks:)Tj
/TT1 1 Tf
( The intruder uses the IP fragmentation option to create extremely )Tj
0 -1.201 TD
(small fragments and force the TCP header information into a separate pac\ket fragment. This )Tj
0 -1.2 TD
(attack is designed to circumvent filtering rules that depend on TCP head\er information. Typically, )Tj
T*
(a packet filter will make a filtering decision on the first fragment of \a packet. All subsequent )Tj
T*
(fragments of that packet are filtered out solely on the basis that they \are part of the packet )Tj
T*
(whose first fragment was rejected. The attacker hopes that the filtering\ router examines only the )Tj
T*
(first fragment and that the remaining fragments are passed through. A ti\ny fragment attack can )Tj
T*
(be defeated by enforcing a rule that the first fragment of a packet must\ contain a predefined )Tj
T*
(minimum amount of the transport header. If the first fragment is rejecte\d, the filter can )Tj
T*
(remember the packet and discard all subsequent fragments.)Tj

14 0 0 14 10 678.3746 Tm(Dual Signature) Tj / TT2 1 Tf
10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 644.1774 Tm(Before looking at the details of the SET protocol, let us discuss an imp\ortant innovation introduced in ) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(SET: the dual signature.The purpose of the dual signature is to link tw\o messages that are intended
for) Tj
T * (two different recipients.In this
case, the customer wants to send the o\rder information\ (OI\) to the) Tj
T * (merchant and the payment information\ (PI\) to the bank.The merchant do\es not need to know the) Tj
T * (customer 's credit card number, and the bank does not need to know the de\tails of the customer'
s order.) Tj
T * (The customer is afforded extra protection in terms of privacy by keeping\these two items separate.) Tj
T * (However, the two items must be linked in a way that can be used to resol\ve disputes
if necessary.The) Tj
T * (link is needed so that the customer can prove that this payment is inten\ded
for this order and not
for) Tj
T * (some other goods or service.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(To see the need
for the link, suppose that the customers send the mercha\nt two messages: a signed OI) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(and a signed PI, and the merchant passes the PI on to the bank.If the m\erchant can capture another OI) Tj
T * (from this customer, the merchant could claim that this OI goes with the\PI rather than the original OI.) Tj
T * (The linkage prevents this.) Tj

10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 628.0008 Tm(Fortezza can be used in a smart card encryption scheme.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(For stream encryption, the compressed message plus the MAC are encrypted\.Note that the MAC is) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(computed before encryption takes place and that the MAC is then encrypte\d along with the plaintext or) Tj
T * (compressed plaintext.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(For block encryption, padding may be added after the MAC prior to encryp\tion.The padding is in the) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(form of a number of padding bytes followed by a one - byte indication of t\he length of the padding.The) Tj
T * (total amount of padding is the smallest amount such that the total size\of the data to be encrypted) Tj
T * (\ (plaintext plus MAC plus padding\) is a multiple of the cipher 's block \length. An example is a plaintext \(or )Tj
T*
(compressed text if compression is used\) of 58 bytes, with a MAC of 20 b\ytes \(using SHA-1\), that is )Tj
T*
(encrypted using a block length of 8 bytes \(e.g., DES\). With the paddin\g.length byte, this yields a total of )Tj
T*
(79 bytes. To make the total an integer multiple of 8, one byte of paddin\g is added.)Tj
0 -2.964 TD
(The final step of SSL Record Protocol processing is to prepend a header,\ consisting of the following fields:)Tj

1.756 - 2.965 Td(It authenticates the Diffie - Hellman exchange to thwart man - in -the - middle\attacks.) Tj - 3.714 - 2.964 Td(We have already discussed Diffie - Hellman.Let us look the remainder of t\hese elements in turn.First, ) Tj
T * (consider the problem of clogging attacks.In this attack, an opponent fo\rges the source address of a) Tj
T * (legitimate user and sends a public Diffie - Hellman key to the victim.The\victim then performs a modular) Tj
T * (exponentiation to compute the secret key.Repeated messages of this type\can) Tj / TT3 1 Tf(clog) Tj / TT2 1 Tf(the victim 's system )Tj

(cookie exchange)Tj
/TT2 1 Tf

0 -1.201 TD
(cookie, in the initial message, which the other side acknowledges. This \acknowledgment must be )Tj
0 -1.2 TD

T*

/TT1 1 Tf

(2.  )Tj
/TT2 1 Tf
1.756 -2.965 Td

T*

T*
(generation and subsequent verification of a cookie. It must not be possi\ble to deduce this secret )Tj
T*

T*

T*

10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 704.4162 Tm(PGP makes use of a compression package called ZIP, written by Jean - lup G\ailly, Mark Adler, and Richard) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(Wales.ZIP is a freeware package written in C that runs as a utility on\UNIX and some other systems.) Tj
T * (ZIP is functionally equivalent to PKZIP, a widely available shareware pa\ckage
for Windows systems) Tj
T * (developed by PKWARE, Inc.The zip algorithm is perhaps the most commonly\used cross - platform) Tj
T * (compression technique; freeware and shareware versions are available
for\Macintosh and other systems) Tj
T * (as well as Windows and UNIX systems.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(Zip and similar algorithms stem from research by Jacob Ziv and Abraham L\empel.In 1977, they) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(described a technique based on a sliding window buffer that holds the mo\st recently processed text) Tj

0 - 2.964 TD(LZ77 and its variants exploit the fact that words and phrases within a t\ext stream\ (image patterns in the) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(

T * (replace the repeated sequence.Over time, codes are reused to capture ne\w sequences.The algorithm) Tj

0 - 1.2 TD(mail format standard, based on technology from RSA Data Security.Althou\gh both PGP and S / MIME are) Tj
T * (on an IETF standards track, it appears likely that S / MIME will emerge as\the industry standard
for) Tj
T * (commercial and organizational use,
while PGP will remain the choice
for\personal e - mail security
for) Tj

T * (and 3851.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(To understand S / MIME, we need first to have a general understanding of t\he underlying e - mail format) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(that it uses, namely MIME.But to understand the significance of MIME, w\e need to go back to the) Tj
T * (traditional e - mail format standard, RFC 822, which is still in common us\e.Accordingly, this section first) Tj
T * (provides an introduction to these two earlier standards and then moves o\n to a discussion of S / MIME.) Tj / TT2 1 Tf
14 0 0 14 10 535.5826 Tm(RFC 822) Tj / TT3 1 Tf
10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 501.3854 Tm(RFC 822 defines a format
for text messages that are sent using electroni\c mail.It has been the standard) Tj
T * (
for Internet - based text mail message and remains in common use.In the R\FC 822 context, messages) Tj
T * (are viewed as having an envelope and contents.The envelope contains wha\tever information is needed) Tj
T * (to accomplish transmission and delivery.The contents compose the object\to be delivered to the) Tj
T * (recipient.The RFC 822 standard applies only to the contents.However, t\he content standard includes a) Tj
T * (set of header fields that may be used by the mail system to create the e\nvelope, and the standard is) Tj
T * (intended to facilitate the acquisition of such information by programs.) Tj

(Arbitrated Digital Signature)Tj
/TT2 1 Tf
10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 157.5085 Tm
(The problems associated with direct digital signatures can be addressed \by using an arbiter.)Tj
0 -2.964 TD
(As with direct signature schemes, there is a variety of arbitrated signa\ture schemes. In general terms, )Tj
0 -1.2 TD
(they all operate as follows. Every signed message from a sender X to a r\eceiver Y goes first to an arbiter )Tj
T*
(A, who subjects the message and its signature to a number of tests to ch\eck its origin and content. The )Tj
T*
(message is then dated and sent to Y with an indication that it has been \verified to the satisfaction of the )Tj
T*
(arbiter. The presence of A solves the problem faced by direct signature \schemes: that X might disown )Tj
T*
(the message.)Tj

T * (is entitled Secure Hash Standard.SHA is based on the hash

T * (adds a C code implementation.) Tj

T * (information, including logon information and database contents.) Tj

10.7692 0 0 10.7692 50 806.0008 Tm(Security involving communications and networks is not as simple as it mi\ght first appear to the) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(novice.The requirements seem to be straightforward; indeed, most of the\major requirements) Tj
T * (
for security services can be given self - explanatory one - word labels: con\fidentiality,
) Tj
T * (authentication, nonrepudiation, integrity.But the mechanisms used to me\et those requirements) Tj
T * (can be quite complex, and understanding them may involve rather subtle r\easoning.) Tj / TT2 1 Tf - 1.756 - 2.964 Td(2.) Tj / TT1 1 Tf
1.756 - 2.965 Td(In developing a particular security mechanism or algorithm, one must alw\ays consider potential) Tj
T * (attacks on those security features.In many cases, successful attacks ar\e designed by looking at) Tj

T * (mechanism.) Tj / TT2 1 Tf - 1.756 - 2.964 Td(3.) Tj / TT1 1 Tf

T * (make sense.) Tj / TT2 1 Tf - 1.756 - 2.964 Td(4.) Tj / TT1 1 Tf

T * (is true both in terms of physical placement\ (e.g., at what points in a\network are certain security) Tj
T * (mechanisms needed\) and in a logical sense[e.g., at what layer or layer\s of an architecture such) Tj
T * (as TCP / IP\ (Transmission Control Protocol / Internet Protocol\) should mec\hanisms be placed].) Tj / TT2 1 Tf - 1.756 - 2.964 Td(5.) Tj / TT1 1 Tf
1.756 - 2.965 Td(Security mechanisms usually involve more than a particular algorithm or\protocol.They usually) Tj
T * (also require that participants be in possession of some secret informati\on\ (e.g., an encryption) Tj

T * (complicate the task of developing the security mechanism.For example, i\f the proper functioning) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(of the security mechanism requires setting time limits on the transit ti\me of a message from) Tj

T * (may render such time limits meaningless.) Tj - 3.714 - 2.964 Td(Thus, there is much to consider.This chapter provides a general overvie\w of the subject matter that) Tj

10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 762.7558 Tm(Another way to apply authentication after encryption is to use two bundl\ed transport SAs, with the inner) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(being an ESP SA and the outer being an AH SA.In this

10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 605.8635 Tm(The use of authentication prior to encryption might be preferable

T * (to do this

0 0.2 0.6 rg / TT3 1 Tf
10.7692 0 0 10.7692 321.1123 485.8623 Tm(Figure 16.9b) Tj
0.2 0.2 0.2 rg(\).For this mode, the ESP header is) Tj - 28.889 - 1.386 Td(prefixed to the packet and then the packet plus the ESP trailer is encry\pted.This method can be used to) Tj
T * (counter traffic analysis.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(Because the IP header contains the destination address and possibly sour\ce routing directives and hop - ) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(by - hop option information, it is not possible simply to transmit the enc\rypted IP packet prefixed by the) Tj
T * (ESP header.Intermediate routers would be unable to process such a packe\t.Therefore, it is necessary) Tj
T * (to encapsulate the entire block\ (ESP header plus ciphertext plus Authen\tication Data,
if present\) with a) Tj
T * (new IP header that will contain sufficient information
for routing but n\ot
for traffic analysis.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(Whereas the transport mode is suitable
for protecting connections betwee\n hosts that support the ESP) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(feature, the tunnel mode is useful in a configuration that includes a fi\rewall or other sort of security) Tj
T * (gateway that protects a trusted network from external networks.In this\latter
case, encryption occurs) Tj
T * (only between an external host and the security gateway or between two se\curity gateways.This relieves) Tj
T * (hosts on the internal network of the processing burden of encryption and\simplifies the key distribution) Tj
T * (task by reducing the number of needed keys.Further, it thwarts traffic\analysis based on ultimate) Tj
T * (destination.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(Consider a
case inwhich an external host wishes to communicate with a h\ost on an internal network) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(protected by a firewall, and in which ESP is implemented in the external\host and the firewalls.The) Tj
T * (following steps occur
for transfer of a transport - layer segment from the\external host to the internal) Tj
T * (host: ) Tj / TT2 1 Tf
1.958 - 2.964 Td(1.) Tj / TT3 1 Tf
1.756 - 2.965 Td(The source prepares an inner IP packet with a destination address of the\target internal host.) Tj
T * (This packet is prefixed by an ESP header; then the packet and ESP traile\r are encrypted and) Tj
T * (Authentication Data may be added.The resulting block is encapsulated wi\th a new IP header) Tj
T * (\ (base header plus optional extensions such as routing and hop - by - hop op\tions
for IPv6\) whose) Tj
T * (destination address is the firewall; this forms the outer IP packet.) Tj / TT2 1 Tf - 1.756 - 2.964 Td(2.) Tj

10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 792.4654 Tm(The shift column transformation is more substantial than it may first ap\pear.This is because) Tj / TT2 1 Tf(CState) Tj / TT1 1 Tf(is) Tj
0 - 1.201 TD(treated as an array of eight 8 - byte rows.Thus, on encryption, the first\8 bytes of the plaintext are) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(copied to the first row of) Tj / TT2 1 Tf(CState) Tj / TT1 1 Tf(, and so on.A column shift moves an individual byte from one row to) Tj
0 - 1.201 TD(another, which is a linear distance of a multiple of 8 bytes.Also note\that the transformation ensures) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(that the 8 bytes of one row are spread out to eight different rows.) Tj / TT3 1 Tf

0.2 0.2 0.2 rg(that

(The PRE-AUTHENT flag, if set, indicates that when the AS received the in\itial request [message \(1\)], it )Tj
T*
(authenticated the client before issuing a ticket. The exact form of this\ preauthentication is left )Tj
T*
(unspecified. As an example, the MIT implementation of version 5 has encr\ypted timestamp )Tj
T*
(preauthentication, enabled by default. When a user wants to get a ticket\, it has to send to the AS a )Tj
T*
(preauthentication block containing a random confounder, a version number\, and a timestamp, encrypted )Tj
T*
(in the client'
s password - based key.The AS decrypts the block and will n\ot send a ticket - granting ticket) Tj
T * (back unless the timestamp in the preauthentication block is within the a\llowable time skew\ (time) Tj
T * (interval to account
for clock drift and network delays\).Another possib\ility is the use of a smart card that) Tj
T * (generates continually changing passwords that are included in the preaut\henticated messages.The) Tj
T * (passwords generated by the card can be based on a user 's password but be\ transformed by the card so )Tj
T*
(that, in effect, arbitrary passwords are used. This prevents an attack b\ased on easily guessed )Tj
T*
(passwords. If a smart card or similar device was used, this is indicated\ by the HW-AUTHENT flag.)Tj

(When a ticket has a long lifetime, there is the potential for it to be s\tolen and used by an opponent for a )Tj

(considerable period. If a short lifetime is used to lessen the threat, t\hen overhead is involved in )Tj
T*

T*
(user'
s secret key, which is clearly risky, or repeatedly ask the user fo\r a password.A compromise) Tj
T * (scheme is the use of renewable tickets.A ticket with the RENEWABLE flag\set includes two expiration) Tj
T * (times: one
for this specific ticket and one that is the latest permissib\le value
for an expiration time.A) Tj
T * (client can have the ticket renewed by presenting it to the TGS with a re\quested new expiration time.If) Tj
T * (the new time is within the limit of the latest permissible value, the TG\S can issue a new ticket with a) Tj
T * (new session time and a later specific expiration time.The advantage of\this mechanism is that the TGS) Tj

T * (decrypting that message.Recall that message encryption / decryption is do\ne with a symmetric) Tj
T * (encryption algorithm.CAST - 128 and IDEA use 128 - bit keys; 3DES uses a 16\8 - bit key.For the following) Tj
T * (discussion, we assume CAST - 128.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(Random 128 - bit numbers are generated using CAST - 128 itself.The input to\the random number) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(generator consists of a 128 - bit key and two 64 - bit blocks that are treat\ed as plaintext to be encrypted.) Tj
T * (Using cipher feedback mode, the CAST - 128 encrypter produces two 64 - bit c\ipher text blocks, which are) Tj
T * (concatenated to form the 128 - bit session key.The algorithm that is used\is based on the one specified) Tj
T * ( in ANSI X12.17.) Tj
0 - 2.964 TD(The "plaintext"
input to the random number generator, consisting of two\64 - bit blocks, is itself derived) Tj
0 - 1.2 TD(from a stream of 128 - bit randomized numbers.These numbers are based on\keystroke input from the) Tj
T * (user.Both the keystroke timing and the actual keys struck are used to g\enerate the randomized stream.) Tj
T * (Thus,

input will be) Tj
T * (generated.This random input is also combined with previous session key\output from CAST - 128 to form) Tj
T * (the key input to the generator.The result, given the effective scrambli\ng of CAST - 128, is to produce a) Tj
T * (sequence of session keys that is effectively unpredictable.) Tj

10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 767.2931 Tm(To recover the signed message and verify the signature, the recipient fi\rst strips off the base64) Tj

/TT3 1 Tf
12.9231 0 0 12.9231 10 695.8904 Tm
(Clear Signing)Tj
/TT2 1 Tf
10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 662.0931 Tm
(Clear signing is achieved using the multipart content type with a signed\ subtype. As was mentioned, this )Tj
T*
(signing process does not involve transforming the message to be signed, \so that the message is sent "in )Tj
T*
(the clear." Thus, recipients with MIME capability but not S/MIME capabil\ity are able to read the incoming )Tj
T*
(message.)Tj
0 -2.964 TD
(A multipart/signed message has two parts. The first part can be any MIME\ type but must be prepared so )Tj
0 -1.2 TD
(that it will not be altered during transfer from source to destination. \This means that if the first part is )Tj
T*
(not 7bit, then it needs to be encoded using base64 or quoted-printable. \Then this part is processed in )Tj
T*
(the same manner as signedData, but in this case an object with signedDat\a format is created that has )Tj
T*
(an empty message content field. This object is a detached signature. It \is then transfer encoded using )Tj
T*
(base64 to become the second part of the multipart/signed message. This s\econd part has a MIME )Tj
T*
(content type of application and a subtype of pkcs7-signature. Here is a \sample message:)Tj
0.475 0 0.161 rg
/TT4 1 Tf
0 -2.736 TD
(Content-Type: multipart/signed;)Tj
0 -1.2 TD
(   protocol="application/pkcs7-signature";)Tj
T*
(   micalg=sha1; boundary=boundary42)Tj
T*
(boundary42)Tj
T*
(Content-Type: text/plain)Tj
T*
(This is a clear-signed message.)Tj
T*
(boundary42)Tj
T*
(Content-Type: application/pkcs7-signature; name=smime.p7s)Tj
T*
(Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64)Tj
T*
(Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=smime.p7s)Tj
T*
(ghyHhHUujhJhjH77n8HHGTrfvbnj756tbB9HG4VQpfyF467GhIGfHfYT6)Tj
T*
(4VQpfyF467GhIGfHfYT6jH77n8HHGghyHhHUujhJh756tbB9HGTrfvbnj)Tj

10.7692 0 0 10.7692 10 255.0931 Tm

T*
